To all those struggling to feed their babies, my message to you is “I hear you.”

Congress hears you and we are taking swift action to make sure this never happens again.

Since the onset of the baby formula shortage, I have been steadfast in my commitment to finding a solution. My bipartisan, Access to Baby Formula Act will ensure flexibility so we can help WIC participants access formula from other companies https://t.co/rJNN5aXWym

Among the most vulnerable, are mothers and babies enrolled in the WIC program who use formula at roughly double the rate of non-participating families – disproportionally impacting communities and families with the highest need.
Families lucky enough to find formula in their local stores, the prices they are paying have increased dramatically, in some cases rising 18% over the past year.

In #CT05 parents have joined FB groups to track where they can find formula. They’re waiting in lines outside of stores, buying sample packs on the streets, even resorting to the dangerous practice of watering down their formula just to stretch their supply. 

They are desperate.

This crisis was caused by the simultaneous manufacturing recall at Abbott Nutrition and ongoing pandemic related supply chain issues. WIC families are impacted the hardest as Abbott formula serves 89% of all infants participating in WIC.

🧵We are in the midst of a national emergency, where families are panicking as they work to prevent their babies from going hungry. Since April, around 40% of formula products were out of stock in 7 states – including my home state of Connecticut.
Now mothers across our country are feeling the desperation, guilt, and anxiety of not being able to adequately feed their babies during the most critical time in their development.

Thank you @JusticeKetanji 
Today was a good day for America. 
Tonight I am filled with joy!
My body trembled, my checks got hot and my eyes filled with tears as I felt the pains of this eerily familiar journey playing out in the chamber.
I never really thought about what it means to not have a Black woman on the Supreme Court until I thought about what it means to not have a Black woman on the Supreme Court.

Today’s confirmation means so much to so many and so much to me! You will never know what it means to not be represented until you belong to a group that is not represented. 
We have so much much work to do to ensure our institutions are representative &  inclusive of all.

I listened, I looked, I watched but what I never expected is what I felt…. 
An overwhelming sense of pride, sadness, relief, a swell of emotions in the pit of my stomach as I witnessed history unfolding before my eyes.
I watched the Vice President preside over the chamber in a compulsory fashion trying to fulfill her duty in an unbiased way.
I looked at staffers and interns trying to curb their enthusiasm, but visibly struck by the magnitude of what they were witnessing.

I listened as Senators accused her of violating the constitution by defending criminals. (which is the most basic of our constitutionally protected rights) 
I listened to Senators comment on how qualified she was before voting NO.

I held on to the sound of every Senator who enthusiastically voted aye and tried to keep a mental tally. I looked up in the galley at a collection of faces I had never seen before holding hands and clearly praying.

Please forgive my late post- but reflection is part of a teacher’s DNA.

Myth #5: SNAP completely covers the costs of food for recipients

Fact: SNAP was built to supplement household food costs, not completely cover them. In fact, prior to the Thrifty Food Plan update, SNAP did not cover the cost of a low-income meal in 96% of U.S. counties. https://t.co/Ga1kooiQAA

Myth #4: SNAP disincentivizes work

Fact: A majority of SNAP recipients who can work, do work. More than 80% of SNAP households work in the year before or the year after receiving SNAP. https://t.co/v8XoClNqw5

Myth #2: Charities can replace the help SNAP provides

Fact: While food banks provide meals for food-insecure communities, SNAP is far more wide-reaching and efficient. SNAP delivers nine times more food to people than all the food banks in the country. https://t.co/VV6rhAqPjl

Myth #3: SNAP is rife with fraud

Fact: SNAP fraud is exceedingly rare. According to the Congressional Research Service, less than .01% of 
benefits have been mistakenly issued due to recipient fraud. https://t.co/02FnPEkkPJ

Myth #1: SNAP drains the economy

Fact: For every dollar utilized by a SNAP recipient, $1.79 is infused into their local economy. Additionally, SNAP lowers healthcare costs by nearly $1,400 per person. https://t.co/mIH2eluwJ1

On October 1st, SNAP benefits will increase by 21% permanently. I know there are many misconceptions about the program. Here are five common myths and facts about SNAP benefits you should know. https://t.co/AQAqZ2n1vi

We must protect the right to vote. It is our most fundamental right and our greatest opportunity to weigh in on all other matters. 

Read my full statement here: https://t.co/SYvzcM3ORc
The decision has unleashed a wave of voter restriction bills aimed at suppressing the rights of our most vulnerable populations, with more than 400 bills introduced at the state level this year.

Americans deserve equal opportunity to choose their elected leaders. I voted to pass the For The People Act (H.R.1), to expand access to the ballot, reduce the influence of money in politics, and implement anti-corruption measures.
While the House has responded to these actions by passing H.R. 1, the For The People Act, the Senate must do the same to restore these vital protections.
